title: Effective Ways to Kill & Repel No-See-Ums In Your House & Yard

steps.title: Place a CO2 trap in your home.
steps.content: Place a CO 2 trap in your home. Simply set the CO 2 trap down and turn it on. It emits a stream of CO 2 gas which attracts no-see-ums and other blood-sucking insects. When they get close to the trap, they are sucked in by a small but powerful vacuum nozzle. [1] X Research source Once the no-see-ums are in the trap, they get dehydrated and eventually die. Position the trap near your front door or somewhere else where no-see-ums are likely to get inside, such as a screened-in porch or mudroom. CO 2 traps can range in price from $40 to upwards of $300, which might make them prohibitively expensive.

steps.title: Trap stray no-see-ums with a mixture of vinegar and soap.
steps.content: Trap stray no-see-ums with a mixture of vinegar and soap. Fill a small bowl with distilled white vinegar or apple cider vinegar. Then, squeeze in a few drops of liquid dish soap and set your trap in a spot where you notice no-see-ums. The midges are drawn to the vinegar but get stuck under the surface of the slippery soap, which kills them. [2] X Research source The dish soap reduces the surface tension of the vinegar, making it impossible for the no-see-ums to escape once they’re inside. This method can be a little smelly. Place your vinegar trap near an open window with good ventilation to help reduce odors.

steps.title: Use insecticides containing DEET or picaridin to blast bugs on sight.
steps.content: Use insecticides containing DEET or picaridin to blast bugs on sight. When you spot no-see-ums or their larvae, spray them with a powerful chemical insecticide. This can stop them in their tracks and kill them. [3] X Research source Don’t go hunting for no-see-ums, as it may be a lost cause. These critters are translucent and often no more than ⅛ inch (3 mm) long! Instead, wait for them to show up. Insecticides can provide a short-term fix by killing off adult flies, but they're not a permanent solution to more serious infestations.

steps.title: Install mesh window and door screens to keep no-see-ums out.
steps.content: Install mesh window and door screens to keep no-see-ums out. Pick up a few rolls of mesh screening that have a tighter weave than the standard 16-mesh size. No-see-ums are incredibly small and often get through standard mesh screening. Then, simply place the mesh screen over your home’s windows and doors. [5] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source Find rolls of mesh screening at any hardware or home improvement store. Some stores even have ultra-fine screening called “No-See-Um Mesh.” Parker recommends treating mesh screens with a pesticide. This makes the screen a physical and chemical barrier, “so even if [no-see-ums] land on it and try and squeeze around it, they will not be successful.” [6] X Expert Source Chris Parker Founder, Parker Eco Pest Control Expert Interview. 18 February 2021. Just use an approved pesticide, like permethrin . [7] X Research source Inspect your screens regularly to ensure they’re free of holes and replace damaged sections as necessary. Parker says even the smallest opening can admit tiny no-see-ums. [8] X Expert Source Chris Parker Founder, Parker Eco Pest Control Expert Interview. 18 February 2021.

steps.title: Leave your air conditioner on to lower the temperature and humidity.
steps.content: Leave your air conditioner on to lower the temperature and humidity. Set your thermostat to around 65–70 °F (18–21 °C) and let it run throughout the day. No-see-ums are attracted to warmth and moisture, so the cooler you keep it in your home, the less likely they are to come around. If blasting your air conditioner nonstop isn’t an option (for instance, if it’s winter), turn on your ceiling fans or place portable fans around your home. This circulates cool air and helps keep any stray no-see-ums from landing on you. [9] X Research source If you live in a hot, humid climate, run a dehumidifier in your home to help reduce the humidity levels.

steps.title: Apply a DEET-based repellent if you’re headed outdoors.
steps.content: Apply a DEET-based repellent if you’re headed outdoors. Before you go outside and into no-see-um territory, spray yourself with an insect repellent containing DEET. This is effective at keeping no-see-ums from biting you, as well as other blood-sucking insects like mosquitos. [10] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source Follow the instructions on the bottle of repellant to ensure you use it safely. [11] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source If you don’t want to use a DEET-based repellent, picaridin and oil of lemon eucalyptus are also effective at warding off no-see-ums. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Spray yourself with lemon, eucalyptus, and citronella essential oils.
steps.content: Spray yourself with lemon, eucalyptus, and citronella essential oils. Lemon , eucalyptus , and citronella essential oils can repel mosquitos, so they might help keep no-see-ums away from you, too. [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Simply fill a small spray bottle with 2 oz (59 ml) of distilled water, 1.5 oz (44 ml) of witch hazel or vodka, and 20 to 30 drops each of lemon, eucalyptus, and citronella essential oils. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Wear long-sleeved clothing in light colors to protect against bites.
steps.content: Wear long-sleeved clothing in light colors to protect against bites. No-see-ums have a hard time biting you through clothes, so wear pants and a long-sleeved shirt if you’re going to be outside to maximize your protection. Choose clothing in light colors, as no-see-ums are attracted to darker colors. [15] X Research source Throw on a hat or wear a mosquito head net to minimize bites around your face, head, and neck. Always wear tall socks and closed-toed shoes when you’re walking in no-see-um-infested areas.

steps.title: Turn off your porch lights at night to avoid attracting no-see-ums.
steps.content: Turn off your porch lights at night to avoid attracting no-see-ums. Get in the habit of switching off all of the lights outside your home around dusk. Many types of insects, including no-see-ums, gravitate towards light sources. Lights essentially act like homing beacons, signaling for bugs to come closer. [16] X Research source Not only will shutting your lights off make you less visible to no-see-ums, but it will also save you money on your monthly utility bill! Parker also recommends shutting your curtains at night—the bugs can be attracted to the light coming out of your windows. [17] X Expert Source Chris Parker Founder, Parker Eco Pest Control Expert Interview. 18 February 2021.

steps.title: Stay away from wet, boggy areas where no-see-ums tend to swarm.
steps.content: Stay away from wet, boggy areas where no-see-ums tend to swarm. One of the best ways to keep no-see-ums away is to simply avoid them. Steer clear of ponds and marshes, as well as any place where water has collected and grown stagnate. If you do find yourself in one of these areas, try not to hang around too long, as your risk of being bitten can increase.

steps.title: Hire an exterminator to deal with infestations.
steps.content: Hire an exterminator to deal with infestations. If none of these solutions help get rid of the no-see-ums, call a professional pest controller to help out. Depending on the extent of the problem, an exterminator may set traps, employ high-strength pesticide sprays, or even decide that a more intensive solution like fumigation is necessary. Because no-see-ums breed so quickly, pesticides can typically only limit the amount of bugs you see, rather than completely eradicating them. Focusing on prevention may be a more effective way to get rid of these pests, which we describe below. [19] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source

steps.title: Clear up areas of standing water on your property.
steps.content: Clear up areas of standing water on your property. Parker says that whenever he receives calls about midges, “there's a water source” that’s attracting them. [20] X Expert Source Chris Parker Founder, Parker Eco Pest Control Expert Interview. 18 February 2021. Walk around your yard and look for places that might be inviting to no-see-ums, like fountains, bird baths, stopped-up gutters, pools of water, and soggy soil. Simply drain the water and fill in moist areas with high-drainage material like gravel or sand. [21] X Research source Check household items for standing water too, like buckets or wheelbarrows. [22] X Research source Fix leaks around your home to prevent water from accumulating, too. Check your pipes, faucets, and drains for leaks and seal them up with putty or tape . Parker recommends walking around your property about once per week to check for any standing water that might have accumulated. [23] X Expert Source Chris Parker Founder, Parker Eco Pest Control Expert Interview. 18 February 2021. You may need to have larger bodies of water like ponds and gulches professionally irrigated in order to dry them out for good.

steps.title: Trim your grass, bushes, and trees regularly.
steps.content: Trim your grass, bushes, and trees regularly. No-see-ums tend to like grassy, shaded areas because they retain more moisture. Simply keep your grass cut short and your shrubs trimmed back to improve air circulation and water evaporation. Then, prune any tree branches that are crossing each other or damaged to reduce stagnant air and shade. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Seal up gaps and holes around your house.
steps.content: Seal up gaps and holes around your house. No-see-ums can get through the tiniest of spaces. Simply walk around the interior and exterior of your home to check for any gaps and fix them. For instance, install weather stripping around doors and windows and seal up exterior holes and cracks with caulk . [25] X Research source

steps.title: No-see-ums are attracted to CO2, skin odors, and heat.
steps.content: No-see-ums are attracted to CO 2 , skin odors, and heat. Like mosquitos and other blood-sucking insects, no-see-ums are drawn to CO 2 and heat because it tells them a host is nearby. These pests are also attracted to the odor of certain chemicals on your skin, like lactic acid. [26] X Research source Activities that increase the amount of CO 2 you exhale and the amount of lactic acid on your skin might make you more attractive to no-see-ums (and mosquitos), like exercising or drinking alcohol. [27] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source No-see-ums and other biting insects tend to be more attracted to dark colors as opposed to light colors. Floral and fruity scents also tend to attract no-see-ums and other blood-sucking pests.

steps.title: No-see-ums seek out and breed in warm, moist environments.
steps.content: No-see-ums seek out and breed in warm, moist environments. Most no-see-ums lay their eggs where the soil is moist, such as near ponds, swamps, streams, and areas of standing water. They prefer warm climates and usually start breeding in the summer. [28] X Research source No-see-ums tend to be most active at dawn and dusk, which are usually the most humid parts of the day. [29] X Research source

steps.title: No-see-ums are less than ⅛-inch (3 mm) long and gray or brown.
steps.content: No-see-ums are less than ⅛-inch (3 mm) long and gray or brown. No-see-ums get their nickname due to the fact that they’re incredibly hard to see. To the naked eye, these tiny midges often look like specks of dust. Up close, they look pretty similar to a house fly. [30] X Trustworthy Source EDIS Electronic database of the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences's peer-reviewed articles Go to source To put the no-see-um’s size into perspective, they’re about as big as the tip of a pencil or the capital “D” on the U.S. dime. No-see-ums are usually easier to see when they’re flying in swarms. No-see-um eggs are about 0.01 in (0.25 mm) long and white to black. No-see-um larvae are 0.08 to 0.2 in (2-5 mm) long and white.

steps.title: Wash the bite with soap and water, then apply a cold compress.
steps.content: Wash the bite with soap and water, then apply a cold compress. Treat no-see-um bites like other insect stings. Clean the affected areas with soap and warm water and pat it dry. Then, press a damp, cool cloth or an ice pack wrapped in a towel to your skin. [31] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Using a cold compress helps lessen pain, swelling, and itchiness. No-see-um bites are often painful and extremely itchy. Like mosquito bites, the spots usually start small and then grow into large, red welts. [32] X Research source

steps.title: Apply hydrocortisone cream or calamine lotion to reduce itchiness.
steps.content: Apply hydrocortisone cream or calamine lotion to reduce itchiness. Both hydrocortisone cream and calamine lotion relieve itchiness to help stop you from scratching the no-see-um bites. Simply apply a thin layer over your bites several times throughout the day. [33] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Follow the instructions on the package to apply the cream or lotion correctly. For a DIY alternative, mix baking soda and water into a paste. Then, apply it over the bites.

steps.title: Take an antihistamine to reduce itchiness and inflammation.
steps.content: Take an antihistamine to reduce itchiness and inflammation. Antihistamine medications like fexofenadine (Allegra) and loratadine (Claritin) can reduce your body’s reaction to the no-see-um bite and lessen itchiness. Simply follow the instructions on the antihistamine’s package for use and dosage information. [34] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
